com.itko.lisa.test

Class Assertion

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.itko.util.test.Assertion
      • com.itko.lisa.test.Assertion
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    com.itko.lisa.model.IWriteXML, NamedType, com.itko.lisa.test.NameGenerator
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    CheckResult

    public abstract class Assertion
extends com.itko.util.test.Assertion
implements com.itko.lisa.model.IWriteXML, NamedType, com.itko.lisa.test.NameGenerator
    This is a base class for handling results from TestNodes All Test Nodes uses this result mechanism. The primary goal of an Assertion sublcass is to perform whatever special validation or testing logic needs to be performed on the result to figure out if that result is what was found. It does this on an assertion model. The logic of an Assertion should take the parameters given to it by the test case author and the result object it is called with to either 'hit' or 'miss'. If the Assertion returns fale from the execute() method, that's considered a miss, and the next Assertion is attempted. If no Assertion hits, then the Node's Next Node parameter is used. If a Assertion returns a hit, that means that the Then Node parameter of the Assertion will be put in line as the next node to execute. For example, if you send a URL to a server and can get any of 3 possible results back, you would want each result possibility represented in the test case document. If 2 of the 3 possible results were bad input errors, you might be able to get away with the "contains" result that's built in (com.itko.lisa.test.AssertionContains). It will just do a sub-string scan of the result for a given token. If the final possible result is a complex thing to figure out in its own right, then you can write a custom Assertion sublcass to figure it out. Maybe anything except these 3 known results are considered a failure of the test entirely, so you would then set the Next Node attribute of the TestNode to be some test-ending, error node (of type com.itko.lisa.ABend).

    See Also:
    TestNode

        Parameters:

        result -
        Returns:

      • evaluate

        protected abstract boolean evaluate(TestExec ts,
               java.lang.Object result)
        This method is called on the subclass to ask it the question: Was this Result object found in the result object given to it?
        Parameters:
        ts - the TestExec (state object) for this test
        result - the result received from the system under test
        Returns:
        false - this object didn't handle it (didn't find its result)

      • initialize

        This method is the subclass initialization that is down-called from the base class to do any subclass-specific initialization from the XML document
        Parameters:
        e - the XML Element of this Assertion; use it to get your child Element data
        Throws:

      • getCustomParameters

        public abstract ParameterList getCustomParameters()
        Implement this method so GUIs and other things can know what your parameter types are; there are very important traits for this ParameterList. There is a default GUI renderer/editor for Results that can be used in most cases. The integration between the compoenent and the UI is this method. The ParameterList's key fields _must_ be the nodes names of the child elements in the XML document that will be generated. For example, the single key for the AssertionContains type is "param".
        Returns:
        a ParameterList of your current state

      • isGlobalAssertion

        public boolean isGlobalAssertion()

        Returns:
        boolean true if it is a test case level assertion.

      • isScopeLocal

        public boolean isScopeLocal()
        This method returns a flag indicating whether the scope of this Assert is Local to the test step or not. Since this is the base class for all asserts, the default is set to true. Individual asserts can override this method to return false instead.
        Returns:
        boolean indicating if this assert should be allowed at test step level.

      • isScopeGlobal

        public boolean isScopeGlobal()
        This method returns a flag indicating whether the scope of this Assert is global to the entire test case or not. Since this is the base class for all asserts, the default is set to true. Individual asserts can override this method to return false instead.
        Returns:
        boolean indicating if this assert should be allowed at test case level.
